message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and urinalysis results suggest nephrotic syndrome. Oral prednisone is the first-line treatment for children with new-onset nephrotic syndrome. It is important to treat this condition to prevent complications such as infections and thrombotic events.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the presence of proteinuria suggest nephrotic syndrome, most likely caused by minimal change disease. Oral prednisone is the preferred treatment for initial management of minimal change disease in children.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of proteinuria suggests nephrotic syndrome, which is commonly caused by minimal change disease or focal segmental glomerulosclerosis in children. Oral prednisone is the first-line treatment for both conditions. Azathioprine and cyclophosphamide may be used in refractory cases or to avoid the side effects of long-term prednisone use, but they are not the first-line treatment. No treatment is not appropriate as nephrotic syndrome can lead to complications such as infections and thromboembolic events.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and history suggest that the child has nephrotic syndrome. The presence of proteinuria confirms this. The most appropriate treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children is oral prednisone. Options B and C are not used as initial treatments and no treatment is not appropriate as this can lead to further complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria and edema. Oral prednisone is the treatment of choice for nephrotic syndrome in children. Azathioprine and cyclophosphamide may be used in some cases, but they are not the first-line treatments. No treatment is not an appropriate option for this patient as nephrotic syndrome can cause complications if left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of proteinuria and edema suggest nephrotic syndrome, which can occur after a viral infection. Oral prednisone is the first-line treatment for children with nephrotic syndrome. Azathioprine and cyclophosphamide are second- or third-line therapies and are not appropriate as initial treatment. No treatment is not an appropriate option as nephrotic syndrome can lead to complications such as infections and blood clots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of lower-extremity edema, proteinuria, and ocular puffiness suggest nephrotic syndrome, which is commonly treated with corticosteroids like oral prednisone. Option B and C are immunosuppressant drugs used for other conditions, and option D is not appropriate as nephrotic syndrome requires treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, such as cough, fever, and proteinuria, indicate the most likely diagnosis is post-infectious glomerulonephritis. The most appropriate treatment is oral prednisone to reduce inflammation and proteinuria. The other options are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and urinalysis suggest the patient may have nephrotic syndrome. Oral prednisone is the first-line treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children. Azathioprine and cyclophosphamide may be used as second-line or adjunctive therapies. No treatment is not appropriate for this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by proteinuria and edema. Prednisone is the first-line treatment for nephrotic syndrome in children. Azathioprine and cyclophosphamide may be used if prednisone is not effective or has significant side effects. No treatment is not an appropriate option for this condition.
